initial_story:
We perhaps should not be surprised that the prime minister has seized upon an extrapolation of Thursday's local election results that pointed to the prospect that the general election could result in a hung parliament in which Labour would be the largest party.

Such a scenario, he argued, would mean that Sir Keir Starmer would be "propped up in Downing Street" by the SNP, the Liberal Democrats, and the Greens.

Many Conservative MPs (and indeed Labour ones too) believe that a poster their party ran in the 2015 election, when the polls were pointing to a hung parliament, showing the then Labour leader, Ed Miliband, in the pocket of the former SNP leader, Alex Salmond, played a key role in delivering the Conservatives a surprise overall majority.

Whether or not that is what happened is not easy for analysts to say. However, British Election Study data collected at the time did not show any marked swing away from Labour among those who came to believe that Mr Miliband would be willing to do a deal with the SNP.

But, in any event, how realistic is it to use the share of the vote won by the parties in local elections to anticipate what might happen in an immediate general election? There are certainly two potential difficulties.

Although the ups and downs in party performance in local elections often run in parallel with the rises and falls in party support in the polls, some people (around one in five) vote differently in local elections than they would in a general election.

As a result the divergence between the level of support parties win in a local election and how well they would perform in a general election has become more marked.

Nowadays the Liberal Democrats consistently outperform their national standing in the local ballot boxes. The same has also come to be true of the Greens, while independent candidates have also enjoyed some notable success in recent years. Labour, in contrast, often do less well in local elections.

Meanwhile, the party political battle in Scotland is now very different from that in England - and the outcome of the current battle north of the border between Labour and the SNP could be crucial to the result of the next election. English local elections do not tell us much about what will happen north of the border.

These developments have made discerning the implications of local elections for the outcome of a general election more difficult.

At the same time, there are two particular features of the results of this year's local elections that make it especially difficult.

First, the polls suggest that more people who voted Conservative in 2019 have now switched to Reform than to Labour. But Reform were only on the ballot paper in one in six council wards. So, it may well be the case that people who would vote Reform if there had been a Reform candidate locally stuck with the Tories instead.

Certainly, Conservative support fell more heavily where Reform did stand. In the BBC's sample of key wards the party's support fell by 19 points in these wards - compared with 11 points in wards where Reform did not stand. Labour, in contrast, did rather better where Reform stood.

That 19-point drop matches the 19-point fall in the average level of Conservative support in the polls since May 2021. That figure may represent a better guide to the Conservatives' immediate prospects in a general election.

Second, the local election results confirm the message from last year's contests that the geography of party support has changed to the Conservatives' disadvantage.

The party's support fell more heavily in wards it was trying to defend.

At the same time, some voters seemingly voted for whichever party was best placed to defeat the Conservatives locally. Labour's support increased most (at the expense of the Liberal Democrats) in wards where they started off second to the Conservatives, while the Liberal Democrats advanced most (and Labour did less well) in wards where were the principal challengers locally.

Indeed, it is these two patterns that help explain why the Conservative Party lost nearly one in two of the council seats it was trying to defend. Conservative MPs would be unwise to assume that the same fate could not also befall them.

Sir John Curtice is Professor of Politics, University of Strathclyde, and Senior Fellow, National Centre for Social Research and 'The UK in a Changing Europe'. He is also co-host of the Trendy podcast.
stories:
The prime minister's prediction of a potential hung parliament in the upcoming general election, with Labour as the largest party, should not come as a shock. In such a situation, Sir Keir Starmer could find himself occupying Downing Street, propped up by the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Greens.

This prospect has been a concern for Conservative and Labour MPs alike. They recall the infamous 2015 election poster depicting Ed Miliband in the SNP leader Alex Salmond's pocket, which was believed to have influenced the Conservatives' unexpected overall victory.

However, it's unclear whether this theory holds true. British Election Study data from that time did not reveal any substantial shift in Labour support among voters who believed Miliband would form an alliance with the SNP.

But, how accurate is it to base general election predictions on the share of votes obtained by parties in local elections? Two primary challenges arise.

First, voting behaviors in local elections can differ significantly from those in a general election. Approximately one in five voters adopt different voting patterns.

Second, local election results have become less indicative of general election outcomes due to various factors. The Liberal Democrats consistently surpass their national standing in local elections, while the Greens and independent candidates have recently experienced success. In contrast, Labour tends to underperform in local elections.

Furthermore, Scotland's party political climate is distinct from England's, and the outcome of the current struggle between Labour and the SNP in Scotland could significantly influence the result of the next election. English local elections provide minimal insight into Scotland's situation.

These trends complicate the process of interpreting the implications of local elections for the outcome of a general election.

Moreover, the 2022 local election results present unique challenges due to the following reasons:

Initially, Reform's presence in one in six council wards may have influenced voting patterns. Voters who would have otherwise supported Reform might have opted to stick with the Conservatives instead, as Reform candidates were not present in all areas.

Second, the geography of party support has evolved to the Conservatives' detriment. The party's support decreased more significantly in wards they were attempting to defend. Conversely, some voters appeared to vote for the party best positioned to challenge the Conservatives locally. Labour gained the most support (at the expense of the Liberal Democrats) in wards where they were initially second to the Conservatives, while the Liberal Democrats made the most progress (and Labour suffered less) in wards where they were the primary challengers.

These trends account for the Conservative Party's loss of almost half of the council seats they were attempting to defend. Conservative MPs should be cautious in assuming they are immune to similar losses.

Professor Sir John Curtice is a Politics Professor at the University of Strathclyde, a Senior Fellow at the National Centre for Social Research, and 'The UK in a Changing Europe.' He is also the co-host of the Trendy podcast.

Predicting general election outcomes based on local election results presents complications. Firstly, local election voting patterns differ significantly from those in a national election, as about one-fifth of voters exhibit divergent voting habits. Secondly, local election results offer limited insight into general election outcomes due to differences in party performance. For instance, the Liberal Democrats perform better in local elections, while Labour underperforms, and the Greens and independent candidates have recently gained traction.

Moreover, Scotland's political landscape varies substantially from England's, and the Labour-SNP conflict in Scotland could significantly influence the subsequent election's outcome. English local elections provide limited understanding of Scotland's circumstances.

The 2022 local election outcomes pose unique challenges:

Initially, Reform's presence in approximately one-sixth of council wards could have swayed voting decisions. Voters who might have supported Reform otherwise could have opted for the Conservatives instead due to the absence of Reform candidates in specific areas.

Secondly, the geography of party support has shifted against the Conservatives' advantage. The party experienced a more considerable decline of support in wards they were defending, while some voters appeared to vote for the party best positioned to challenge the Conservatives locally. Labour made the most gains (at the expense of the Liberal Democrats) in wards where they were initially second to the Conservatives, while the Liberal Democrats gained the most ground (and Labour suffered less) in wards where they were the primary contenders.

These trends account for the Conservative Party's loss of approximately half of the council seats they were targeting. Conservative MPs should exercise caution when assuming they are invulnerable to comparable losses.

Predicting election results based on local election data entails difficulties. Voting patterns in local elections diverge significantly from those in national elections. Around one-fifth of voters exhibit inconsistent voting behavior. Furthermore, local election outcomes provide restricted insights into national election outcomes due to disparities in party performance. For example, the Liberal Democrats excel in local elections, whereas Labour underperforms, and the Greens and independent candidates have recently gained traction.

Moreover, Scotland's political terrain differs substantially from England's, and Labour-SNP tensions in Scotland could considerably influence the election's outcome. Local elections in England offer limited comprehension of Scotland's distinct circumstances.

The complexities of the 2022 local election results encompass:

Firstly, the emergence of Reform as a factor in approximately one-sixth of council wards might have swayed voters' decisions. Some voters who may have otherwise supported Reform opted for the Conservatives instead due to the absence of Reform candidates.

Secondly, the geography of party support has shifted against the Conservatives' advantage. The party experienced a more considerable decline in support in wards they were defending. Conversely, some voters seemed to vote for the party most likely to challenge the Conservatives locally. Labour recorded the most gains (at the expense of the Liberal Democrats) in wards where they were initially second to the Conservatives, while the Liberal Democrats gained the most ground (and Labour suffered less) in wards where they were the front-runners.

These trends led to the Conservative Party losing approximately half of the council seats they had intended to win. Conservative MPs must exercise caution when assuming they are impervious to similar losses.
